articles.title: D√°n kifejez√©sek f√©lt√©kenys√©ghez √©s bizalomhoz
articles.content:
A d√°n kult√∫ra a hygge szellem√©ben kezeli a kapcsolatokat. Ha d√°n anyanyelv≈± partnered van, ezek a kifejez√©sek seg√≠tenek.

## Kifejez√©sek a f√©lt√©kenys√©ghez

### 1. "Jeg bliver jaloux, n√•r du..."
**Kiejt√©s:** Jaj bl√≠ver zsal√∫, nor du

**Jelent√©s:** F√©lt√©keny leszek, amikor te...

### 2. "Jeg har brug for at blive beroliget"
**Kiejt√©s:** Jaj har br√∫ for at bl√≠ve berol√≠get

**Jelent√©s:** Megnyugtat√°sra van sz√ºks√©gem

### 3. "Jeg stoler p√• dig, men jeg k√¶mper med mine f√∏lelser"
**Kiejt√©s:** Jaj szt√≥ler p√≥ daj, men jaj kemper med m√≠ne f√∂lelser

**Jelent√©s:** Megb√≠zom benned, de k√ºzd√∂k az √©rz√©seimmel

### 4. "Kan vi tale om, hvad der skete?"
**Kiejt√©s:** Kan vi tale om, va der szkete

**Jelent√©s:** Besz√©lhet√ºnk arr√≥l, ami t√∂rt√©nt?

### 5. "Jeg vil ikke v√¶re jaloux, men..."
**Kiejt√©s:** Jaj vil ikke v√©re zsal√∫, men

**Jelent√©s:** Nem akarok f√©lt√©keny lenni, de...

### 6. "Jeg stoler fuldst√¶ndigt p√• dig"
**Kiejt√©s:** Jaj szt√≥ler fulsztendigt p√≥ daj

**Jelent√©s:** Teljesen megb√≠zom benned

### 7. "Du er den eneste for mig"
**Kiejt√©s:** Du √§r den en√©szte for maj

**Jelent√©s:** Te vagy az egyetlen nekem

### 8. "Jeg ville aldrig g√∏re noget for at s√•re dig"
**Kiejt√©s:** Jaj ville √°ldrig g√∂re noget for at sz√≥re daj

**Jelent√©s:** Soha nem tenn√©k semmit, ami f√°jna neked

### 9. "Der er intet mellem os"
**Kiejt√©s:** Der √§r intet mellem osz

**Jelent√©s:** Nincs k√∂zt√ºnk semmi

### 10. "Jeg er dig tro"
**Kiejt√©s:** Jaj √§r daj tr√≥

**Jelent√©s:** H≈± vagyok hozz√°d

### 11. "Lad os v√¶re √¶rlige over for hinanden"
**Kiejt√©s:** Lad osz v√©re √§rlige √≥ver for hin√°nden

**Jelent√©s:** Legy√ºnk ≈ëszint√©k egym√°ssal

### 12. "Jeg vil ikke have, at jalousi kommer mellem os"
**Kiejt√©s:** Jaj vil ikke ha, at zsal√∫szi kommer mellem osz

**Jelent√©s:** Nem akarom, hogy a f√©lt√©kenys√©g k√∂z√©nk √°lljon

## √ñsszefoglal√°s

A d√°n kult√∫ra a hygge szellem√©ben kezeli a kapcsolatokat ‚Äì a f√©lt√©kenys√©g is nyugodtan megbesz√©lhet≈ë.

articles.title: Russian Date Night: 55+ Romantic Words
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import ConjugationTable from '@components/ConjugationTable.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Date nights are essential for any relationship, and when you're dating someone who speaks Russian, knowing the right vocabulary can make your evenings even more special. Let's explore all the words and phrases you need for the perfect romantic outing!

## Planning the Date

<PhraseOfDay
  word="–î–∞–≤–∞–π —Å—Ö–æ–¥–∏–º –Ω–∞ —Å–≤–∏–¥–∞–Ω–∏–µ"
  translation="Let's go on a date"
  pronunciation="da-VAY skho-DIM na svi-DA-ni-ye"
  context="The perfect way to invite your partner for a romantic evening out."
/>

### Asking Your Partner Out

<VocabCard
  word="–¢—ã —Å–≤–æ–±–æ–¥–Ω–∞/—Å–≤–æ–±–æ–¥–µ–Ω —Å–µ–≥–æ–¥–Ω—è –≤–µ—á–µ—Ä–æ–º?"
  translation="Are you free tonight? (f/m)"
  pronunciation="Ty sva-BOD-na / sva-BO-dyen se-VOD-nya VYE-che-ram"
  example="–¢—ã —Å–≤–æ–±–æ–¥–Ω–∞? –•–æ—á—É –ø—Ä–∏–≥–ª–∞—Å–∏—Ç—å —Ç–µ–±—è –Ω–∞ —É–∂–∏–Ω."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–î–∞–≤–∞–π –∫—É–¥–∞-–Ω–∏–±—É–¥—å —Å—Ö–æ–¥–∏–º"
  translation="Let's go somewhere"
  pronunciation="da-VAY ku-DA-ni-but skho-DIM"
  example="–î–∞–≤–∞–π –∫—É–¥–∞-–Ω–∏–±—É–¥—å —Å—Ö–æ–¥–∏–º —Å–µ–≥–æ–¥–Ω—è!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–ö—É–¥–∞ –±—ã —Ç—ã —Ö–æ—Ç–µ–ª–∞/—Ö–æ—Ç–µ–ª –ø–æ–π—Ç–∏?"
  translation="Where would you like to go? (f/m)"
  pronunciation="ku-DA by ty kha-TYE-la / kha-TYEL pay-TI"
  example="Ask about their preferences."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–£ –º–µ–Ω—è –µ—Å—Ç—å —Å—é—Ä–ø—Ä–∏–∑ –¥–ª—è —Ç–µ–±—è"
  translation="I have a surprise for you"
  pronunciation="U me-NYA yest syur-PRIZ dlya te-BYA"
  example="Building anticipation for the date."
/>

<CultureTip title="Who Pays?" flag="üá∑üá∫">
In traditional Russian dating culture, men typically pay for dates, especially in the early stages of a relationship. However, modern couples often split bills or take turns. It's always nice to offer: "–î–∞–≤–∞–π —è –∑–∞–ø–ª–∞—á—É" (Let me pay) or "–î–∞–≤–∞–π –ø–æ–ø–æ–ª–∞–º" (Let's split it).
</CultureTip>

## At the Restaurant

### Getting a Table

<VocabCard
  word="–°—Ç–æ–ª–∏–∫ –Ω–∞ –¥–≤–æ–∏—Ö, –ø–æ–∂–∞–ª—É–π—Å—Ç–∞"
  translation="A table for two, please"
  pronunciation="STO-lik na dva-IKH, pa-ZHA-lus-ta"
  example="Essential for reservations."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–£ –≤–∞—Å –µ—Å—Ç—å —Å–≤–æ–±–æ–¥–Ω—ã–π —Å—Ç–æ–ª–∏–∫?"
  translation="Do you have a free table?"
  pronunciation="U vas yest sva-BOD-ny STO-lik"
  example="When you don't have a reservation."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–ú—ã –∑–∞–∫–∞–∑—ã–≤–∞–ª–∏ —Å—Ç–æ–ª–∏–∫"
  translation="We reserved a table"
  pronunciation="My za-KA-zy-va-li STO-lik"
  example="–ú—ã –∑–∞–∫–∞–∑—ã–≤–∞–ª–∏ —Å—Ç–æ–ª–∏–∫ –Ω–∞ —Å–µ–º—å —á–∞—Å–æ–≤."
/>

### Ordering Food

<VocabCard
  word="–ú–æ–∂–Ω–æ –º–µ–Ω—é, –ø–æ–∂–∞–ª—É–π—Å—Ç–∞"
  translation="May I have the menu, please"
  pronunciation="MOZH-na me-NYU, pa-ZHA-lus-ta"
  example="Start with the menu."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–ß—Ç–æ —Ç—ã –±—É–¥–µ—à—å?"
  translation="What will you have?"
  pronunciation="Shto ty BU-dyesh"
  example="Asking your partner's choice."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–ß—Ç–æ –≤—ã –ø–æ—Ä–µ–∫–æ–º–µ–Ω–¥—É–µ—Ç–µ?"
  translation="What do you recommend?"
  pronunciation="Shto vy pa-re-ka-myen-DU-ye-tye"
  example="To the waiter."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–Ø –≤–æ–∑—å–º—É —ç—Ç–æ"
  translation="I'll take this"
  pronunciation="Ya vaz-MU E-ta"
  example="When ordering."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–¢–æ –∂–µ —Å–∞–º–æ–µ –¥–ª—è –º–µ–Ω—è"
  translation="The same for me"
  pronunciation="To zhe SA-ma-ye dlya me-NYA"
  example="Ordering the same as your partner."
/>

### Restaurant Vocabulary

| Russian | Pronunciation | English |
|---------|---------------|---------|
| –ó–∞–∫—É—Å–∫–∏ | za-KUS-ki | Appetizers |
| –û—Å–Ω–æ–≤–Ω–æ–µ –±–ª—é–¥–æ | as-nav-NO-ye BLYU-da | Main course |
| –î–µ—Å–µ—Ä—Ç | de-SYERT | Dessert |
| –ù–∞–ø–∏—Ç–∫–∏ | na-PIT-ki | Drinks |
| –í–∏–Ω–æ | vi-NO | Wine |
| –°—á—ë—Ç | shchot | Bill/Check |
| –û—Ñ–∏—Ü–∏–∞–Ω—Ç | a-fi-tsi-ANT | Waiter |
| –ß–∞–µ–≤—ã–µ | cha-ye-VY-ye | Tip |

<VocabCard
  word="–°—á—ë—Ç, –ø–æ–∂–∞–ª—É–π—Å—Ç–∞"
  translation="The bill, please"
  pronunciation="Shchot, pa-ZHA-lus-ta"
  example="When you're ready to leave."
/>

<CultureTip title="Tipping in Russia" flag="üá∑üá∫">
Tipping is appreciated but not obligatory in Russia. 10-15% is generous for good service. You can say "–°–¥–∞—á–∏ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–¥–æ" (Keep the change) if paying cash, or add the tip to the card payment.
</CultureTip>

## Romantic Dining Phrases

<VocabCard
  word="–î–∞–≤–∞–π –∑–∞–∫–∞–∂–µ–º –≤–∏–Ω–æ"
  translation="Let's order wine"
  pronunciation="da-VAY za-KA-zhem vi-NO"
  example="–ö—Ä–∞—Å–Ω–æ–µ –∏–ª–∏ –±–µ–ª–æ–µ?"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–ó–∞ –Ω–∞—Å!"
  translation="To us!"
  pronunciation="Za nas"
  example="A romantic toast."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–ó–∞ –ª—é–±–æ–≤—å!"
  translation="To love!"
  pronunciation="Za lyu-BOF"
  example="Another classic toast."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–≠—Ç–æ –æ—á–µ–Ω—å –≤–∫—É—Å–Ω–æ"
  translation="This is very delicious"
  pronunciation="E-ta O-chen VKUS-na"
  example="Complimenting the food."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–•–æ—á–µ—à—å –ø–æ–ø—Ä–æ–±–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å?"
  translation="Do you want to try?"
  pronunciation="KHO-chesh pa-pro-BA-vat"
  example="Sharing food romantically."
/>

## Going to the Movies

<VocabCard
  word="–î–∞–≤–∞–π –ø–æ–π–¥—ë–º –≤ –∫–∏–Ω–æ"
  translation="Let's go to the movies"
  pronunciation="da-VAY pay-DYOM v ki-NO"
  example="Suggesting a movie date."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–ö–∞–∫–æ–π —Ñ–∏–ª—å–º —Ö–æ—á–µ—à—å –ø–æ—Å–º–æ—Ç—Ä–µ—Ç—å?"
  translation="What movie do you want to watch?"
  pronunciation="ka-KOY film KHO-chesh pas-mat-RYET"
  example="Let them choose."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–î–≤–∞ –±–∏–ª–µ—Ç–∞, –ø–æ–∂–∞–ª—É–π—Å—Ç–∞"
  translation="Two tickets, please"
  pronunciation="Dva bi-LYE-ta, pa-ZHA-lus-ta"
  example="At the ticket counter."
/>

### Movie Vocabulary

| Russian | Pronunciation | English |
|---------|---------------|---------|
| –ö–∏–Ω–æ—Ç–µ–∞—Ç—Ä | ki-na-te-ATR | Movie theater |
| –§–∏–ª—å–º | film | Movie |
| –ö–æ–º–µ–¥–∏—è | ka-MYE-di-ya | Comedy |
| –†–æ–º–∞–Ω—Ç–∏–∫–∞ | ra-MAN-ti-ka | Romance |
| –ü–æ–ø–∫–æ—Ä–Ω | pop-KORN | Popcorn |
| –°–µ–∞–Ω—Å | se-ANS | Showing |
| –°—É–±—Ç–∏—Ç—Ä—ã | sub-TIT-ry | Subtitles |

<CultureTip title="Russian Cinema Etiquette" flag="üá∑üá∫">
Russian moviegoers tend to be quiet during films. Holding hands, cuddling, and sharing snacks are perfectly acceptable for couples. Many cinemas have "love seats" (–¥–≤–æ–π–Ω—ã–µ –∫—Ä–µ—Å–ª–∞) - wider seats for couples!
</CultureTip>

## Other Date Activities

### Walking Together

<VocabCard
  word="–î–∞–≤–∞–π –ø–æ–≥—É–ª—è–µ–º"
  translation="Let's take a walk"
  pronunciation="da-VAY pa-gu-LYA-yem"
  example="–î–∞–≤–∞–π –ø–æ–≥—É–ª—è–µ–º –ø–æ –ø–∞—Ä–∫—É."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–ö—Ä–∞—Å–∏–≤—ã–π –≤–µ—á–µ—Ä"
  translation="Beautiful evening"
  pronunciation="kra-SI-vy VYE-cher"
  example="–ö–∞–∫–æ–π –∫—Ä–∞—Å–∏–≤—ã–π –≤–µ—á–µ—Ä!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–ó–¥–µ—Å—å —Ç–∞–∫ —Ä–æ–º–∞–Ω—Ç–∏—á–Ω–æ"
  translation="It's so romantic here"
  pronunciation="Zdyes tak ra-man-TICH-na"
  example="Setting the mood."
/>

### Theater and Concerts

<VocabCard
  word="–•–æ—á–µ—à—å –ø–æ–π—Ç–∏ –≤ —Ç–µ–∞—Ç—Ä?"
  translation="Do you want to go to the theater?"
  pronunciation="KHO-chesh pay-TI v te-ATR"
  example="For a cultural date."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–î–∞–≤–∞–π –ø–æ—Å–ª—É—à–∞–µ–º –º—É–∑—ã–∫—É"
  translation="Let's listen to music"
  pronunciation="da-VAY pas-LU-sha-yem MU-zy-ku"
  example="Concert or music at home."
/>

### Dancing

<VocabCard
  word="–î–∞–≤–∞–π –ø–æ—Ç–∞–Ω—Ü—É–µ–º"
  translation="Let's dance"
  pronunciation="da-VAY pa-tan-TSU-yem"
  example="–ü–æ—Ç–∞–Ω—Ü—É–π —Å–æ –º–Ω–æ–π!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–¢—ã –ø—Ä–µ–∫—Ä–∞—Å–Ω–æ —Ç–∞–Ω—Ü—É–µ—à—å"
  translation="You dance beautifully"
  pronunciation="Ty prek-RAS-na tan-TSU-yesh"
  example="A sweet compliment."
/>

## During the Date

### Sweet Things to Say

<VocabCard
  word="–ú–Ω–µ —Ç–∞–∫ —Ö–æ—Ä–æ—à–æ —Å —Ç–æ–±–æ–π"
  translation="I feel so good with you"
  pronunciation="Mnye tak kha-ra-SHO s ta-BOY"
  example="Express your happiness."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–¢—ã –ø—Ä–µ–∫—Ä–∞—Å–Ω–æ –≤—ã–≥–ª—è–¥–∏—à—å —Å–µ–≥–æ–¥–Ω—è"
  translation="You look wonderful today"
  pronunciation="Ty prek-RAS-na VYG-lya-dish se-VOD-nya"
  example="Start with a compliment."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–Ø —Ç–∞–∫ —Ä–∞–¥/—Ä–∞–¥–∞, —á—Ç–æ –º—ã –≤–º–µ—Å—Ç–µ"
  translation="I'm so glad we're together (m/f)"
  pronunciation="Ya tak rad / RA-da, shto my VMYES-tye"
  example="Express gratitude for the relationship."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–≠—Ç–æ—Ç –≤–µ—á–µ—Ä –Ω–µ–∑–∞–±—ã–≤–∞–µ–º—ã–π"
  translation="This evening is unforgettable"
  pronunciation="E-tat VYE-cher nye-za-by-VA-ye-my"
  example="Make them feel special."
/>

### Getting Closer

<VocabCard
  word="–ú–æ–∂–Ω–æ —Ç–µ–±—è –æ–±–Ω—è—Ç—å?"
  translation="Can I hug you?"
  pronunciation="MOZH-na te-BYA ab-NYAT"
  example="Asking sweetly."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–ú–æ–∂–Ω–æ —Ç–µ–±—è –ø–æ—Ü–µ–ª–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å?"
  translation="Can I kiss you?"
  pronunciation="MOZH-na te-BYA pa-tse-la-VAT"
  example="The romantic moment."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–ò–¥–∏ –∫–æ –º–Ω–µ"
  translation="Come to me"
  pronunciation="i-DI ka MNYE"
  example="An intimate invitation."
/>

<CultureTip title="Public Displays of Affection" flag="üá∑üá∫">
Russians are generally comfortable with couples holding hands, hugging, and even kissing in public. However, excessive PDA is frowned upon. A balance of affection and modesty is appreciated.
</CultureTip>

## Ending the Evening

<VocabCard
  word="–ü—Ä–æ–≤–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å —Ç–µ–±—è –¥–æ–º–æ–π?"
  translation="Shall I walk you home?"
  pronunciation="pra-va-DIT te-BYA da-MOY"
  example="The gentlemanly offer."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–Ø –ø—Ä–µ–∫—Ä–∞—Å–Ω–æ –ø—Ä–æ–≤—ë–ª/–ø—Ä–æ–≤–µ–ª–∞ –≤—Ä–µ–º—è"
  translation="I had a wonderful time (m/f)"
  pronunciation="Ya prek-RAS-na pra-VYOL / pra-vye-LA VRYE-mya"
  example="Ending on a positive note."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–î–∞–≤–∞–π –ø–æ–≤—Ç–æ—Ä–∏–º"
  translation="Let's do it again"
  pronunciation="da-VAY pav-ta-RIM"
  example="Planning the next date."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–ö–æ–≥–¥–∞ —É–≤–∏–¥–∏–º—Å—è —Å–Ω–æ–≤–∞?"
  translation="When will we see each other again?"
  pronunciation="kag-DA u-VI-dim-sya SNO-va"
  example="Already looking forward to more."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="–°–ø–∞—Å–∏–±–æ –∑–∞ —á—É–¥–µ—Å–Ω—ã–π –≤–µ—á–µ—Ä"
  translation="Thank you for a wonderful evening"
  pronunciation="spa-SI-ba za chu-DYES-ny VYE-cher"
  example="Express your gratitude."
/>

## Date Ideas Vocabulary

| Russian | Pronunciation | English |
|---------|---------------|---------|
| –†–µ—Å—Ç–æ—Ä–∞–Ω | res-ta-RAN | Restaurant |
| –ö–∞—Ñ–µ | ka-FE | Cafe |
| –ü–∞—Ä–∫ | park | Park |
| –ü–ª—è–∂ | plyazh | Beach |
| –ú—É–∑–µ–π | mu-ZEY | Museum |
| –ö–æ–Ω—Ü–µ—Ä—Ç | kan-TSERT | Concert |
| –í—ã—Å—Ç–∞–≤–∫–∞ | VYS-tav-ka | Exhibition |
| –ü—Ä–æ–≥—É–ª–∫–∞ | pra-GUL-ka | Walk/Stroll |
| –ü–∏–∫–Ω–∏–∫ | pik-NIK | Picnic |
| –£–∂–∏–Ω –ø—Ä–∏ —Å–≤–µ—á–∞—Ö | U-zhin pri sve-CHAKH | Candlelit dinner |


## Quick Reference: Date Night Phrases

### Planning

| Russian | English |
|---------|---------|
| –î–∞–≤–∞–π —Å—Ö–æ–¥–∏–º –Ω–∞ —Å–≤–∏–¥–∞–Ω–∏–µ | Let's go on a date |
| –¢—ã —Å–≤–æ–±–æ–¥–Ω–∞/—Å–≤–æ–±–æ–¥–µ–Ω? | Are you free? |
| –£ –º–µ–Ω—è –µ—Å—Ç—å –∏–¥–µ—è | I have an idea |

### At Restaurant

| Russian | English |
|---------|---------|
| –°—Ç–æ–ª–∏–∫ –Ω–∞ –¥–≤–æ–∏—Ö | Table for two |
| –ß—Ç–æ –ø–æ—Ä–µ–∫–æ–º–µ–Ω–¥—É–µ—Ç–µ? | What do you recommend? |
| –°—á—ë—Ç, –ø–æ–∂–∞–ª—É–π—Å—Ç–∞ | Bill, please |
| –ó–∞ –Ω–∞—Å! | To us! |

### During the Date

| Russian | English |
|---------|---------|
| –ú–Ω–µ —Ö–æ—Ä–æ—à–æ —Å —Ç–æ–±–æ–π | I feel good with you |
| –¢—ã –ø—Ä–µ–∫—Ä–∞—Å–Ω–æ –≤—ã–≥–ª—è–¥–∏—à—å | You look wonderful |
| –≠—Ç–æ –±—ã–ª–æ —á—É–¥–µ—Å–Ω–æ | This was wonderful |

### End of Evening

| Russian | English |
|---------|---------|
| –ü—Ä–æ–≤–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å —Ç–µ–±—è –¥–æ–º–æ–π? | Walk you home? |
| –î–∞–≤–∞–π –ø–æ–≤—Ç–æ—Ä–∏–º | Let's do it again |
| –°–ø–æ–∫–æ–π–Ω–æ–π –Ω–æ—á–∏ | Good night |

<CTA
  text="Practice Russian with AI voice conversations, save words to Love Log, and send romantic Word Gifts!"
  buttonText="Learn Russian Together"
/>

articles.title: Expressions de Mariage en N√©erlandais : Guide Complet
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import ConjugationTable from '@components/ConjugationTable.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Le mariage est l'un des moments les plus magiques de la vie d'un couple. Si vous vous mariez dans un pays n√©erlandaisphone, ou si vous avez des invit√©s qui parlent n√©erlandais, ce guide vous aidera √† ma√Ætriser tout le vocabulaire essentiel. D√©couvrez les expressions les plus importantes pour vivre pleinement ce jour sp√©cial en n√©erlandais.

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Wil je met me trouwen?"
  translation="Veux-tu m'√©pouser ?"
  pronunciation="[prononciation]"
  context="La question la plus importante de votre vie - la demande en mariage"
/>

## Les Bases : F√©licitations aux Mari√©s

<VocabCard
  word="Gefeliciteerd met jullie huwelijk!"
  translation="F√©licitations pour votre mariage !"
  pronunciation="[prononciation]"
  example="Gefeliciteerd met jullie huwelijk! Mogen jullie lang en gelukkig leven!"
/>

### Expressions de F√©licitations

| N√©erlandais | Fran√ßais | Contexte |
|---------|----------|----------|
| Gefeliciteerd met jullie huwelijk! | F√©licitations pour votre mariage ! | Universel |
| Mogen jullie lang en gelukkig leven | Que vous viviez heureux pour toujours ! | Romantique |

<CultureTip title="Traditions de Mariage" flag="üá≥üá±">
Dans les pays n√©erlandaisphones, les traditions de mariage varient selon les r√©gions. Le toast aux mari√©s est un moment important de la c√©l√©bration o√π famille et amis partagent leurs v≈ìux de bonheur.
</CultureTip>

## Vocabulaire de la C√©r√©monie

<VocabCard
  word="Ja, ik wil"
  translation="Oui, je le veux"
  pronunciation="[prononciation]"
  example="Quand on lui a demand√©, il/elle a r√©pondu : 'Ja, ik wil'."
/>

### Les Participants au Mariage

| N√©erlandais | Fran√ßais |
|---------|----------|
| bruid | la mari√©e |
| bruidegom | le mari√© |
| bruidsmeisje | demoiselle d'honneur |
| getuige | t√©moin du mari√© |
| bruiloft | mariage |
| ceremonie | c√©r√©monie |
| receptie | r√©ception |
| huwelijksreis | lune de miel |

### Les √âl√©ments de la C√©r√©monie

| N√©erlandais | Fran√ßais |
|---------|----------|
| geloften | v≈ìux de mariage |
| trouwring | alliance |
| boeket | bouquet |
| gangpad | all√©e centrale |
| altaar | autel |
| sluier | voile |
| bruidstaart | g√¢teau de mariage |
| openingsdans | premi√®re danse |

<VocabCard
  word="trouwring"
  translation="alliance"
  pronunciation="[prononciation]"
  example="Les trouwring symbolisent l'amour √©ternel."
/>

## La Demande en Mariage

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Wil je met me trouwen?"
  translation="Veux-tu m'√©pouser ?"
  pronunciation="[prononciation]"
  context="La question la plus romantique"
/>

### Vocabulaire des Fian√ßailles

| N√©erlandais | Fran√ßais |
|---------|----------|
| aanzoek | demande en mariage |
| verloving | fian√ßailles |
| verloofde | fianc√©(e) |

<CultureTip title="La Demande en Mariage" flag="üá≥üá±">
La demande en mariage est un moment unique. En n√©erlandais, la phrase traditionnelle "Wil je met me trouwen?" est souvent accompagn√©e de rituels romantiques comme mettre un genou √† terre.
</CultureTip>

## Messages pour Cartes de Mariage

<VocabCard
  word="Mogen jullie lang en gelukkig leven"
  translation="Que vous viviez heureux pour toujours"
  pronunciation="[prononciation]"
  example="Message parfait pour une carte de mariage."
/>

### Formules de V≈ìux

- **Gefeliciteerd met jullie huwelijk!** - F√©licitations pour votre mariage !
- **Mogen jullie lang en gelukkig leven** - Que vous viviez heureux pour toujours !

## La R√©ception

### Vocabulaire de la F√™te

| N√©erlandais | Fran√ßais |
|---------|----------|
| receptie | r√©ception |
| bruidstaart | g√¢teau de mariage |
| openingsdans | premi√®re danse |
| toast | toast |
| boeket | bouquet |

<VocabCard
  word="toast"
  translation="toast"
  pronunciation="[prononciation]"
  example="Le t√©moin a port√© un toast aux mari√©s."
/>

## Pour Aller Plus Loin

Maintenant que vous ma√Ætrisez le vocabulaire du mariage en n√©erlandais, pourquoi ne pas explorer d'autres expressions romantiques ? D√©couvrez nos guides sur les [expressions romantiques en n√©erlandais](/fr/blog/dutch-romantic-phrases-for-every-occasion) ou les [petits noms affectueux](/fr/blog/dutch-pet-names-terms-of-endearment).

Que vous disiez "Ja, ik wil" bient√¥t ou que vous f√™tiez le mariage d'un proche, ces expressions vous permettront de partager pleinement la joie de ce moment unique.

<CTA />

articles.title: Polsk Udtale for Begyndere: S√•dan Taler du Rent med Din Elskede
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import ConjugationTable from '@components/ConjugationTable.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Forestil dig at sige "kocham ciƒô" (jeg elsker dig) til din polske partner ‚Äì og de forst√•r dig perfekt! Polsk udtale kan virke skr√¶mmende med alle de konsonanter, men sammen kan I mestre det. N√•r du l√¶rer disse lyde, √•bner du d√∏ren til dybere samtaler og [romantiske √∏jeblikke](/learn/da/pl/romantic-phrases-for-every-occasion/) med din elskede.

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Kocham ciƒô"
  translation="Jeg elsker dig"
  pronunciation="KOH-hahm chyeh"
  context="Den vigtigste s√¶tning ‚Äì perfekt at √∏ve udtale med!"
/>

## De Polske Lyde: Ikke S√• Mystiske Som De Ser Ud

Polsk bruger nogle lyde, som ikke findes i dansk ‚Äì men fortvivl ikke! T√¶nk p√• det som at l√¶re nye k√¶rtegnens sprog. De fleste lyde har faktisk n√¶sten identiske "f√¶tre" i dansk.

### De Bl√∏de Lyde (Sis-lydene)

De ber√∏mte polske "sis-lyde" ‚Äì **≈õ**, **ƒá**, **≈Ñ** ‚Äì er faktisk ret k√¶rlige:
- **≈ö** lyder som "sh" i "shop", bare bl√∏dere ‚Äì sig det som hvis du hvisker til din partner
- **ƒÜ** som "tj" i "tju-hej", men bl√∏dere
- **≈É** som "nj" i "Spanien"

<VocabCard
  word="≈õwiecie"
  translation="verden / k√¶re"
  pronunciation="SHVYEH-cheh"
  example="M√≥j ≈õwiecie! (Min k√¶re!)"
/>

<CultureTip flag="üáµüá±" title="K√¶lenavne og Udtale">
Polakker elsker k√¶lenavne! N√•r du mestrer de bl√∏de lyde, kan du sige "kochanie" (k√¶re) eller "misiu" (lille bamse) helt rigtigt. Det vil smelte din partners hjerte!
</CultureTip>

## Vokalerne: Fem Simple Lyde

Polske vokaler er faktisk lettere end danske ‚Äì de udtales altid ens:

| Bogstav | Lyd | Som i dansk | Eksempel |
|---------|-----|-------------|----------|
| **A** | "ah" | "far" | mama (mor) |
| **E** | "eh" | "bed" | serce (hjerte) |
| **I** | "ee" | "bi" | mi≈Çy (s√∏d) |
| **O** | "oh" | "g√•" | kocham (elsker) |
| **U** | "oo" | "gul" | buzia (kys) |

<VocabCard
  word="buzia"
  translation="kys / mund"
  pronunciation="BOO-zhah"
  example="Daj mi buziaka! (Giv mig et kys!)"
/>

## Konsonant-kombinationer: Det Hele Handler Om Flydende Bev√¶gelser

Polske ord kan have mange konsonanter sammen ‚Äì men t√¶nk p√• det som en dans, ikke en kamp!

### De Mest Almindelige Kombinationer

- **cz** = "tsh" (som "tj" i "tjat")
- **sz** = "sh" (som "shop")
- **dz** = "ds" (som "beds")
- **d≈∫** = bl√∏dt "dj" (som "dj" i "dj√¶vle")

<ConjugationTable
  verb="Kochaƒá"
  meaning="at elske"
  conjugations={[
    { person: "Jeg", polish: "kocham", english: "jeg elsker" },
    { person: "Du", polish: "kochasz", english: "du elsker" },
    { person: "Han/Hun", polish: "kocha", english: "han/hun elsker" },
    { person: "Vi", polish: "kochamy", english: "vi elsker" },
    { person: "I (flertal)", polish: "kochacie", english: "I elsker" },
    { person: "De", polish: "kochajƒÖ", english: "de elsker" }
  ]}
/>

## Praktiske S√¶tninger til Daglige Samtaler

√òv disse med din partner ‚Äì de d√¶kker 80% af daglige interaktioner:

| Polsk | Udtale | Dansk | Brug |
|-------|--------|-------|------|
| **Jak siƒô masz?** | yahk shyeh mahsh | Hvordan har du det? | Hverdagshilsen |
| **Co robisz?** | tsoh ROH-beesh | Hvad laver du? | Vis interesse |
| **Tƒôskniƒô za tobƒÖ** | TESH-nee zah TOH-bahn | Jeg savner dig | Romantisk |
| **Jeste≈õ piƒôkna** | YES-tesh pee-ENG-nah | Du er smuk | Kompliment |

<CultureTip flag="üáµüá±" title="Intonationens Magi">
Polakker bruger melodisk intonation ‚Äì stemmen stiger og falder. N√•r du siger noget k√¶rligt, lad din stemme blive bl√∏dere og mere sangagtig. Det g√∏r en k√¶mpe forskel!
</CultureTip>

## De Sv√¶reste Lyde (Og S√•dan Mestrer Du Dem)

### **≈Å** ‚Äì Den Stille Lyd
Dette er IKKE "L"! Det lyder som "w" i "water":
- **≈Å** = "w" (som engelsk)
- **L** = almindeligt "L"

<VocabCard
  word="b≈Çogos≈Çawie≈Ñstwo"
  translation="velsignelse"
  pronunciation="bwoh-goh-SHAH-vyen-stwoh"
  example="B≈Çogos≈Çawie≈Ñstwo rodzic√≥w (For√¶ldrenes velsignelse)"
/>

### **Rz** og **≈ª** ‚Äì Den Summende Lyd
Begge lyder som "s" i "m√•ske", men **rz** kan v√¶re h√•rdere:
- **Rz** = "zh" (som "s" i "m√•ske")
- **≈ª** = "zh" (samme lyd)

## √òvelser I Kan Lave Sammen

### 1. Spejl-√∏velsen
St√• foran et spejl sammen. Sig de sv√¶re ord samtidig og kig p√• hinandens mundbev√¶gelser. Start med:
- **cztery** (fire) ‚Äì **CHTE-rih**
- **dziƒôkujƒô** (tak) ‚Äì **djen-KOO-yeh**

### 2. Historie-spillet
Byg en k√¶rlighedshistorie med de nye ord. Hver person tilf√∏jer en s√¶tning med et nyt ord.

### 3. K√¶rligheds-alfabetet
L√¶r alfabetet gennem k√¶rlighedsord:
- **A** jak **akceptacja** (accept)
- **B** jak **blisko≈õƒá** (n√¶rhed)
- **C** jak **czu≈Ço≈õƒá** (k√¶rtegn)

## Almindelige Fejl (Og Hvordan Du Undg√•r Dem)

| Fejl | Korrekt | Forklaring |
|------|---------|------------|
| "Koh-ham" | **KOH-hahm** | Stress f√∏rste stavelse i "kocham" |
| "Tak" som "tak" | **tahk** | Kort, klart "a" ‚Äì ikke dansk "tak" |
| "Cze≈õƒá" som "tjest" | **cheshtch** | Bl√∏dt, men med "sh"-lyd |
| "Dziƒôkujƒô" med "d" | **djen-KOO-yeh** | Start med bl√∏dt "dj" |

<CultureTip flag="üáµüá±" title="N√•r Det G√•r Galt">
Polakker synes det er charmerende, n√•r udl√¶ndinge pr√∏ver! Hvis du laver en fejl, griner de med dig ‚Äì ikke af dig. Din partner vil elske din indsats!
</CultureTip>

## Din Udtale-hurtigguide (Gem Dette!)

**Vokaler**: Altid pure ‚Äì A (ah), E (eh), I (ee), O (oh), U (oo)

**Konsonanter**:
- **C** = "ts" (altid)
- **Cz** = "tsh"
- **Sz** = "sh"
- **≈Å** = "w"
- **Rz/≈ª** = "zh"

**Stress**: N√¶stsidste stavelse (med f√• undtagelser)

## Hvad Nu?

Nu hvor du mestrer de grundl√¶ggende lyde, kan du udforske [polske k√¶lenavne til din partner](/learn/da/pl/polish-pet-names-for-your-partner/) eller l√¶re [hvordan man m√∏der familien](/learn/da/pl/meeting-your-partner-s-family/) med selvtillid. Hver ny lyd √•bner d√∏re til dybere samtaler og st√¶rkere b√•nd.

<CTA />

sections: ## De Sv√¶reste Lyde (Og S√•dan Mestrer Du Dem)

articles.title: 50+ Engelse Koosnaampjes om Harten te Laten Smelten
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Bijnamen en koosnaampjes zijn een universele manier om genegenheid te tonen. In het Engels is er een verrassend grote variatie aan lieve benamingen. Deze gids neemt je mee door alle categorie√´n, van traditioneel tot trendy.

## De Oorsprong van Engelse Koosnaampjes

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Pet name"
  translation="Koosnaampje"
  pronunciation="pet neim"
  context="De Engelse term voor een liefkozende bijnaam."
/>

Het woord "pet name" komt van het idee dat we onze geliefden behandelen met dezelfde tederheid als huisdieren. Dit verklaart waarom veel koosnaampjes van dieren komen!

## Klassieke Koosnaampjes

### De Tijdloze Favorieten

<VocabCard
  word="Honey"
  translation="Honing/Schatje"
  pronunciation="ha-nie"
  example="Honey, can you come here for a second? (Schatje, kun je even hier komen?)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Sweetheart"
  translation="Liefje/Hartje"
  pronunciation="swiet-haart"
  example="Sweetheart, don't forget your keys. (Liefje, vergeet je sleutels niet.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Darling"
  translation="Lieveling"
  pronunciation="daar-ling"
  example="Darling, I've missed you so much. (Lieveling, ik heb je zo gemist.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Dear"
  translation="Schat/Lieve"
  pronunciation="dier"
  example="Yes, dear. (Ja, schat.)"
/>

<CultureTip title="Generaties" flag="üë¥üëµ">
"Darling" en "dear" worden vaak als ouderwets gezien door jongere generaties. Toch zijn ze perfect voor formele of traditionele contexten, en veel oudere stellen gebruiken ze nog steeds liefdevol.
</CultureTip>

## Moderne Koosnaampjes

### Populair bij Jongere Generaties

<VocabCard
  word="Babe"
  translation="Schat"
  pronunciation="beib"
  example="Babe, look at this! (Schat, kijk hier eens!)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Baby"
  translation="Baby/Schatje"
  pronunciation="bei-bie"
  example="Baby, you're the best. (Schatje, jij bent de beste.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Boo"
  translation="Schatje (slang)"
  pronunciation="boe"
  example="Hey boo, what's up? (Hey schatje, wat is er?)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Bae"
  translation="Schat (before anyone else)"
  pronunciation="bei"
  example="Spending the weekend with bae. (Het weekend doorbrengen met mijn schat.)"
/>

<CultureTip title="Sociale Media Invloed" flag="üì±">
"Bae" werd populair via sociale media en staat voor "before anyone else" (voor iedereen anders). Hoewel het een paar jaar geleden op zijn hoogtepunt was, wordt het nog steeds gebruikt, vooral in een ironische of speelse context.
</CultureTip>

## Eten-Gerelateerde Koosnaampjes

Engelsen vergelijken hun geliefden graag met zoete dingen:

<VocabCard
  word="Sugar"
  translation="Suiker/Zoetje"
  pronunciation="sjoe-ger"
  example="Hi sugar, how was work? (Hoi zoetje, hoe was je werk?)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Honey bunch"
  translation="Honingbonbontje"
  pronunciation="ha-nie bantj"
  example="I love you, honey bunch. (Ik hou van je, liefje.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Sweetie pie"
  translation="Zoete taart"
  pronunciation="swie-tie pai"
  example="Goodnight, sweetie pie. (Welterusten, liefje.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Cupcake"
  translation="Cupcakeje"
  pronunciation="kap-keik"
  example="You're adorable, cupcake. (Je bent schattig, cupcakeje.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Muffin"
  translation="Muffin"
  pronunciation="ma-fin"
  example="Morning, muffin! (Goedemorgen, muffin!)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Pumpkin"
  translation="Pompoentje"
  pronunciation="pamp-kin"
  example="What's wrong, pumpkin? (Wat is er, pompoentje?)"
/>

## Dieren-Gerelateerde Koosnaampjes

<VocabCard
  word="Bunny"
  translation="Konijntje"
  pronunciation="ba-nie"
  example="Come here, bunny. (Kom hier, konijntje.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Kitty/Kitten"
  translation="Katje/Poesje"
  pronunciation="ki-tie/ki-ten"
  example="Hey kitty, missed me? (Hey katje, heb je me gemist?)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Bear/Teddy bear"
  translation="Beer/Knuffelbeer"
  pronunciation="ber/te-die ber"
  example="My big teddy bear! (Mijn grote knuffelbeer!)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Puppy"
  translation="Puppy"
  pronunciation="pa-pie"
  example="You're like an excited puppy! (Je bent als een enthousiaste puppy!)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Bug/Love bug"
  translation="Beestje/Liefdesbeestje"
  pronunciation="bag/lav bag"
  example="Hey love bug! (Hey liefje!)"
/>

## Uiterlijk-Gerelateerde Koosnaampjes

<VocabCard
  word="Beautiful"
  translation="Mooie"
  pronunciation="bjoe-ti-foel"
  example="Good morning, beautiful. (Goedemorgen, mooie.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Handsome"
  translation="Knappe"
  pronunciation="hen-sem"
  example="Looking good, handsome. (Je ziet er goed uit, knappe.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Gorgeous"
  translation="Prachtige"
  pronunciation="gor-djes"
  example="Hello gorgeous! (Hallo, prachtige!)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Cutie"
  translation="Schatje"
  pronunciation="kjoe-tie"
  example="You're such a cutie. (Je bent zo'n schatje.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Cutie pie"
  translation="Schattig taartje"
  pronunciation="kjoe-tie pai"
  example="Aww, you're a cutie pie. (Aww, je bent een schatje.)"
/>

## Regionale Variaties

Het Engels verschilt sterk per regio:

### Brits Engels

| Koosnaampje | Betekenis | Regio |
|-------------|-----------|-------|
| Love | Lief/Schat | Hele VK |
| Pet | Lief | Noord-Engeland |
| Duck/Ducky | Eendje | Midlands |
| Flower | Bloem | Wales |
| Hen | Kipje | Schotland |

### Amerikaans Engels

| Koosnaampje | Betekenis | Regio |
|-------------|-----------|-------|
| Sugar | Suiker | Zuiden |
| Pumpkin | Pompoen | Overal |
| Sunshine | Zonneschijn | Overal |
| Doll | Popje | New York |

<CultureTip title="Regionale Charme" flag="üó∫Ô∏è">
In het noorden van Engeland kun je door vreemden "pet" of "love" genoemd worden in winkels. Dit is niet flirterig, maar gewoon vriendelijk. In het zuiden van de VS is "sugar" heel normaal, zelfs tussen onbekenden!
</CultureTip>

## Speelse en Unieke Koosnaampjes

<VocabCard
  word="Snookums"
  translation="Snoepje"
  pronunciation="snoe-kums"
  example="I love you, snookums. (Ik hou van je, snoepje.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Snuggle bunny"
  translation="Knuffelkonijntje"
  pronunciation="sna-gel ba-nie"
  example="Come here, my snuggle bunny. (Kom hier, mijn knuffelkonijntje.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Cuddle bear"
  translation="Knuffelbeer"
  pronunciation="ka-del ber"
  example="You're my favorite cuddle bear. (Je bent mijn favoriete knuffelbeer.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Lovey-dovey"
  translation="Tortelduifje"
  pronunciation="la-vie da-vie"
  example="Look at those lovey-doveys. (Kijk die tortelduifjes eens.)"
/>

## Bijnamen voor Specifieke Eigenschappen

Vaak ontstaan bijnamen uit persoonlijke eigenschappen:

| Eigenschap | Mogelijke Bijnaam |
|------------|-------------------|
| Klein van stuk | Little one, Tiny, Shorty |
| Rood haar | Red, Ginger |
| Sterk | Big guy, Muscles |
| Slim | Smarty, Brains |
| Grappig | Funny face, Silly |

## Je Eigen Koosnaampje Cre√´ren

De beste koosnaampjes zijn vaak persoonlijk en uniek:

1. **Gebaseerd op herinneringen** - Van jullie eerste date of een grappige gebeurtenis
2. **Van binnenpretjes** - Iets dat alleen jullie begrijpen
3. **Afgeleid van namen** - Speelse versies van elkaars naam
4. **Van eigenaardigheden** - Schattige gewoontes die je partner heeft

<CultureTip title="Uniek is Mooi" flag="üíï">
De meest betekenisvolle koosnaampjes zijn vaak degene die niemand anders zou begrijpen. Een vriend van me noemt zijn vrouw "Pickle" vanwege een grappige gebeurtenis op hun eerste date. Het klinkt raar, maar voor hen is het perfect!
</CultureTip>

## Do's en Don'ts

### Do's
- Kies een koosnaampje dat past bij je relatie
- Wissel af tussen verschillende namen
- Vraag of je partner het prettig vindt

### Don'ts
- Gebruik geen koosnaampje dat je partner niet leuk vindt
- Wees niet te intiem in professionele settings
- Gebruik geen koosnaampje voor je ex bij je nieuwe partner

## Snelle Referentie per Gelegenheid

| Gelegenheid | Aanbevolen |
|-------------|------------|
| Thuis, ontspannen | Babe, honey, hun |
| Romantisch diner | Darling, beautiful, my love |
| In gezelschap | Dear, sweetheart |
| Speels moment | Silly, pumpkin, bunny |
| Troostend | Love, angel, sweetie |
